questions.text: Which substance is involved in the conjugation process in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucuronic Acid

Explanation

  • Glucuronidation is a biochemical process in which a glucuronic acid molecule is attached to a substance, making it more water-soluble and easier to excrete.
  • This process is essential for the detoxification and elimination of substances like bilirubin, drugs, and hormones in the liver.

Synthetic Reaction

Description

Examples

Glucuronidation

Conjugation with glucuronic acid via UDP-glucuronosyl transferases (UGTs).

Chloramphenicol, aspirin, paracetamol, morphine, bilirubin, steroid hormones, thyroxine.

Acetylation

Conjugation with acetyl CoA, mediated by N-acetyl transferases.

Isoniazid, sulfonamides, hydralazine, dapsone, clonazepam.

Methylation

Methylation of amines and phenols by methyl transferases using methionine or cysteine as donors.

Adrenaline, histamine, methyldopa, captopril, mercaptopurine.

Sulfation

Conjugation of phenols and steroids with sulfate by sulfotransferases (SULTs).

Chloramphenicol, methyldopa, adrenal steroids.

Glycine Conjugation

Conjugation with glycine for drugs with carboxylic acid groups.

Salicylates, nicotinic acid.

Glutathione Conjugation

Conjugation of reactive intermediates with glutathione via glutathione-S-transferases.

Paracetamol (reactive intermediates), quinones, epoxides.

Ribonucleoside Synthesis

Conjugation for activation of purine and pyrimidine antimetabolites.

Cancer chemotherapeutic agents.

Hyaluronic Acid (Option A): Hyaluronic acid is a glycosaminoglycan involved in extracellular matrix formation and lubrication of joints. It does not play a role in hepatic conjugation processes.

Gluconic Acid (Option C): Gluconic acid is a product of glucose oxidation and is not involved in the conjugation process in the liver.


Glycolic Acid (Option D): Glycolic acid is an alpha-hydroxy acid commonly associated with skincare and is not involved in hepatic conjugation.

questions.text: What is the process of converting unconjugated substances into conjugated forms called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucuronidation

Explanation

  • Glucuronidation is a biochemical process in which a glucuronic acid molecule is attached to a substance, making it more water-soluble and easier to excrete. This process is essential for the detoxification and elimination of substances like bilirubin, drugs, and hormones in the liver.

 

Synthetic Reaction

Description

Examples

Glucuronidation

Conjugation with glucuronic acid via UDP-glucuronosyl transferases (UGTs).

Chloramphenicol, aspirin, paracetamol, morphine, bilirubin, steroid hormones, thyroxine.

Acetylation

Conjugation with acetyl CoA, mediated by N-acetyl transferases.

Isoniazid, sulfonamides, hydralazine, dapsone, clonazepam.

Methylation

Methylation of amines and phenols by methyl transferases using methionine or cysteine as donors.

Adrenaline, histamine, methyldopa, captopril, mercaptopurine.

Sulfation

Conjugation of phenols and steroids with sulfate by sulfotransferases (SULTs).

Chloramphenicol, methyldopa, adrenal steroids.

Glycine Conjugation

Conjugation with glycine for drugs with carboxylic acid groups.

Salicylates, nicotinic acid.

Glutathione Conjugation

Conjugation of reactive intermediates with glutathione via glutathione-S-transferases.

Paracetamol (reactive intermediates), quinones, epoxides.

Ribonucleoside Synthesis

Conjugation for activation of purine and pyrimidine antimetabolites.

Cancer chemotherapeutic agents.

 

Glycation (Option A): Glycation is the non-enzymatic attachment of sugars to proteins or lipids, typically seen in conditions like diabetes. It does not involve the conjugation of substances in the way glucuronidation does.

Glycosylation (Option C): Glycosylation involves the enzymatic attachment of a sugar molecule (often glucose or mannose) to proteins or lipids, typically in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus. It is distinct from glucuronidation and is not primarily involved in detoxification.

Oxidation (Option D): Oxidation refers to the chemical reaction where a molecule loses electrons, often resulting in the addition of oxygen or the removal of hydrogen. While oxidation can modify molecules, it does not specifically refer to the conjugation process like glucuronidation.

questions.text: The active site of an enzyme is most complementary to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Substrate

Explanation:

Properties of Enzyme

Nature of Enzymes

Enzymes are proteins, heat-sensitive, water-soluble

Efficiency

Enzymes can accelerate reactions by factors 10^6 to 10^9 or more.

Specificity

Enzymes act on specific substrates and can distinguish stereoisomers.

Cofactors/Coenzymes

Some enzymes need non-protein molecules (cofactors or coenzymes) to be active.

Substrate Binding

Enzymes bind substrates at multiple points, creating chiral products from non-chiral substrates.

Transition State

Enzymes stabilize the transition state, lowering activation energy.

Reversibility

Enzymes can catalyze both forward and reverse reactions.

Regulation

Activity is regulated by pH, temperature, inhibitors, and activators.

Active site

  • The region where the substrate binds and undergoes a chemical reaction
  • It is most complimentary to enzyme-substrate

questions.text: In which organelle is DNA present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mitochondria:

  • DNA is present in the mitochondria, which are double-membraned organelles found in the cells of most eukaryotic organisms. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is a small circular molecule separate from the nuclear DNA. It carries genetic information essential for the functioning of mitochondria and plays a crucial role in energy production through oxidative phosphorylation.

Incorrect Options:
Option B - Lysosome: Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles containing enzymes responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials and substances. They do not contain DNA; their primary function is related to digestion and waste disposal within the cell.

Option C - Endoplasmic Reticulum: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is an organelle involved in the synthesis, folding, modification, and transport of proteins and lipids. It does not contain DNA. The ER is composed of membranous structures and is mainly responsible for the manufacturing and transportation of molecules within the cell.

Option D - Cytoplasm: The cytoplasm is the gel-like substance found inside the cell, which includes various organelles and is the site of many cellular processes. While the cytoplasm contains various molecules and structures necessary for cell function, DNA itself is not typically present in the cytoplasm. DNA is primarily found within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells, where it houses the genetic information required for cell function and development.

questions.text: In which organelle is DNA present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Mitochondria

Explanation:

  • DNA is present in the mitochondria, which are double-membraned organelles found in the cells of most eukaryotic organisms. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is a small circular molecule separate from the nuclear DNA. It carries genetic information essential for the functioning of mitochondria and plays a crucial role in energy production through oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Lysosome (Option B) are membrane-bound organelles containing enzymes responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials and substances. Their primary function is related to digestion and waste disposal within the cell.

Endoplasmic Reticulum (Option C) is an organelle involved in the synthesis, folding, modification, and transport of proteins and lipids. The ER is composed of membranous structures and is mainly responsible for the manufacturing and transportation of molecules within the cell.

Cytoplasm (Option D) is the gel-like substance found inside the cell, which includes various organelles and is the site of many cellular processes. The cytoplasm contains various molecules and structures necessary for cell function, DNA is not present in the cytoplasm. DNA is primarily found within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells, where it houses the genetic information required for cell function and development.

questions.text: What is the cause of elevated H+ ions in the intermembrane space of mitochondria?

choices.text: Water retention in inner mitochondrial membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Decreased oxidative phosphorylation

 

Explanation:

Decreased oxidative phosphorylation:

  • The intermembrane space of the mitochondria is an important site for generating an electrochemical gradient that drives ATP synthesis through oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Increased H+ ions in the intermembrane space can be due to decreased oxidative phosphorylation, which can be caused by a range of factors.
  • Mitochondrial dysfunction, genetic mutations affecting mitochondrial function, or exposure to toxins or drugs that affect mitochondrial respiration.

 

Increased ATP production (Option B): ATP production through oxidative phosphorylation depends on the electrochemical gradient generated by the transport of H+ ions from the intermembrane space to the mitochondrial matrix.

 

Reduced chemiosmosis (Option C): Increased H+ ions in the intermembrane space can lead to increased chemiosmosis, which is the process by which the H+ gradient generated across the inner mitochondrial membrane drives ATP synthesis through oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Water retention in the inner mitochondrial space (Option D): Increased H+ ions in the intermembrane space are unrelated to water retention in the inner mitochondrial space.However, increased H+ ions in the intermembrane space can lead to decreased water concentration due to changes in pH.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome results from abnormality in formation of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Peroxisomes

 

Explanation:

Zellweger syndrome/Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome results from an abnormality in the formation of peroxisomes, which are cellular organelles responsible for various metabolic functions, including:

 

  • Defective Peroxisomal Biogenesis: Mutations in PEX genes disrupt the assembly and function of peroxisomes.
  • Key Consequence: Impaired breakdown of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), branched-chain fatty acids and other metabolic substrates leads to severe metabolic dysfunction.
  • It is part of the peroxisome biogenesis disorder (PBD) spectrum.
  • Accumulates C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and exhibit generalised loss of peroxisomal functions.
  • Management: Docosahexaenoic acid, Lorenzo oil and Cholic acid.

questions.text: Refsum disease is caused due to absence of which of the following enzymes?

choices.text: Absence of alpha oxidation in peroxisomes.
Absence of beta oxidation in peroxisomes.
Absence of alpha oxidation in lysosomes.
Absence of beta oxidation in lysosomes.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Absence of alpha oxidation in peroxisomes.

 

Explanation:

  • Refsum disease is a rare inherited disorder caused by mutation in PHYH gene, leading to deficiency of the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase, which is involved in the alpha-oxidation of phytanic acid (a fatty acid).
  • Alpha oxidation occurs in peroxisomes and aids in fatty acid breakdown.

Triad:

  • Cerebellar Ataxia
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Chronic polyneuropathy

questions.text: The subcellular organelle which is associated with the killing of viruses and bacteria is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Lysosome

Explanation:

  • Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles containing hydrolytic enzymes (like proteases, lipases, and nucleases) that digest and destroy pathogens, including viruses and bacteria, through a process called phagocytosis.
  • After engulfment by phagocytes (macrophages), the pathogen is enclosed in a phagosome, which fuses with a lysosome to form a phagolysosome, where enzymatic degradation occurs.

Peroxisome (Option A): Involved in fatty acid oxidation and reactive oxygen species detoxification.

Mitochondria (Option B): Powerhouse of the cell, involved in ATP production.

Golgi apparatus (Option D): Involved in protein modification, packaging, and transport.

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics depicted in the graph is suggestive of
questions.solution:
The graph depicted is of Michaelis Menten's kinetics. Michaelis Menten's kinetics is intended to explain the broad mechanism and rate of enzyme-catalyzed reactions. The Michaelis-Menten equation is widely used to analyze enzyme kinetics and determine important parameters such as Vmax and Km.

Michalis Menten equation:

V = Vmax x S / (Km + S)

Where,

V = Velocity of reaction

Vmax = Maximum velocity of the reaction

S = Substrate concentration

Km = Michaelis constant = Substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2)

Allosteric activation (Option A) They are regulatory enzymes /multi-subunit enzymes. The activator shifts the curve to the left while the inhibitor shifts the cure to right

Cooperative binding (Option B) One substrate binding to an enzyme increases the affinity for other substrates for enzymes.

Sigmoid curve (Option D) In the presence of allosteric modifiers the graph of enzyme–catalyzed reaction obtained is a sigmoid / S-shaped graph.

questions.text: Which mechanism is responsible for the inhibition of the acetylcholinesterase enzyme by organophosphorus compounds?
questions.solution:
Correct Choice: C) Irreversible competitive inhibition

Explanation:

  • Organophosphorus compounds, such as certain pesticides and nerve agents, can irreversibly inhibit the activity of acetylcholinesterase (AChE
  • The inhibition caused by organophosphorus compounds is considered irreversible because these compounds form strong covalent bonds with the active site of the enzyme. They covalently bind to the serine residue within the active site of AChE, forming a stable complex that cannot be easily reversed or dissociated.

 

Reversible competitive inhibition (Option A) occurs when an inhibitor molecule competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme.

Non-competitive inhibition (Option B) occurs when an inhibitor binds to a site on the enzyme other than the active site, altering its conformation and reducing its activity.

Suicidal inhibition (Option D) is another term used to describe the irreversible nature of inhibition caused by organophosphorus compounds. It refers to the fact that the inhibitor "kills" the enzyme by permanently modifying it, leading to its inactivation.

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 880KCal

Explanation:

  • To calculate the number of calories delivered in the TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) bag, we need to know the caloric value of each macronutrient.

The caloric values per gram for each macronutrient are as follows:

  • Glucose: 4 calories per gram
  • Amino acids: 4 calories per gram
  • Lipids (fats): 9 calories per gram

 

Now let's calculate the calories for each component of the TPN bag:

  • Glucose: 100g of glucose * 4 calories/gram = 400 calories.
  • Amino acids: 30g of amino acids * 4 calories/gram = 120 calories.
  • Lipids: 40g of lipids * 9 calories/gram = 360 calories.

 

Now, let's add up the calories from each component: 400 calories (glucose) + 120 calories (amino acids) + 360 calories (lipids) = 880 calories

questions.text: The Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is given by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b) A

Explanation:

  • In enzyme-catalyzed reactions, the Gibbs free energy curve typically shows a lower activation energy compared to the uncatalyzed reaction (represented by a higher activation energy barrier).
  • This is one of the key effects of enzymes, as they lower the activation energy, allowing the reaction to proceed more rapidly.
  • Gibbs free energy change, symbolized as AG, is a thermodynamic quantity that measures the energy available in a chemical reaction to do useful work at constant temperature and pressure.

 

The Gibbs free energy change is defined by the equation: AG = AH - TAS

Where:

  • AG is the Gibbs free energy change
  • AH is the change in enthalpy (heat content) of the system
  • T is the temperature in Kelvin
  • AS is the change in entropy (disorder) of the system

 

Option B: All the reactions have a transition state, but not all reactions have an intermediate state.

Option C: Transition energy intermediate never has lower energy compared to the product.

Option D: Free energy change cannot be a straight line. It has to pass through a a high energy intermediate state.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has the highest catalytic efficiency?

choices.text: Km of an enzyme = 10 micromole and Kcat = 20 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2000 nanomole and Kcat = 50 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 4 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec:

Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec:

  • Catalytic efficiency, also known as specificity constant, is a measure of how effectively an enzyme converts substrate to product.
  • It is calculated as the ratio of the catalytic rate constant (Kcat) to the Michaelis constant (Km).
  • Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec: Catalytic efficiency = Kcat / Km = 200 / 2 = 100 per micromole per sec.
  • Catalytic efficiency refers to the measure of how effectively an enzyme catalyzes a specific reaction.
  • It is a measure of the enzyme's ability to convert substrate molecules into products within a given time frame.
  • Catalytic efficiency is commonly expressed using the Michaelis-Menten equation, which relates the rate of the enzymatic reaction to the concentration of the substrate.
  • The two important parameters used to evaluate catalytic efficiency are the turnover number (kcat) and the Michaelis constant (Km).
